contentrichtext.text: A '''Thorne–Żytkow object''' or '''TŻO''' is a hypothetical type of [[star]] wherein a [[red giant]] or [[red supergiant|supergiant]] contains a [[neutron star]] at its core. Such objects were hypothesized by [[Kip Thorne]] and [[Anna Żytkow]] in 1977.<ref name=tz77>{{cite journal|last=Thorne|first=Kip|coauthors=Żytkow, Anna|title=Stars with degenerate neutron cores. I – Structure of equilibrium models|journal=[[The Astrophysical Journal]]|year=1977|month=March|volume=212|issue=1|pages=832–858|doi=10.1086/155109|bibcode=1977ApJ...212..832T}}</ref> Though some objects have been suggested as candidates, none have been confirmed.<ref name=UAq>{{cite journal|last=Vanture|first=Andrew|coauthors=Zucker, Daniel; Wallerstein, George|title=U Aquarii a Thorne–Żytkow Object?|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|year=1999|month=April|volume=514|issue=2|pages=932–938|doi=10.1086/306956|bibcode=1999ApJ...514..932V}}</ref> A Thorne–Żytkow object is formed when a neutron star collides with a star, typically a red giant or supergiant. The colliding objects can simply be wandering stars. This is only likely to occur in extremely crowded [[globular cluster]]s. Alternatively, the neutron star could form in a binary system. Because no supernova is perfectly symmetric, the neutron star will be left with a small velocity relative to its original orbit. This [[Supernova#Asymmetry|kick]] may cause its new orbit to intersect with its companion, or, if its companion is a main-sequence star, be engulfed by its companion when it evolves into a red giant.<ref name=brandt95>{{cite journal|last=Brandt|first=Niel|coauthors=Podsiadlowski, Philipp|title=The effects of high-velocity supernova kicks on the orbital properties and sky distributions of neutron-star binaries|journal=[[Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society]]|year=1995|month=May|volume=274|issue=2|pages=461–484|url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1995MNRAS.274..461B|bibcode = 1995MNRAS.274..461B }}</ref> Once the neutron star enters the red giant, [[drag (physics)|drag]] between the neutron star and the outer, diffuse layers of the red giant causes the binary star system's [[orbit]] to decay, and the neutron star and core of the red giant spiral inward toward one another. Depending on their initial separation, this process may take hundreds of years. When the two finally collide, the neutron star and red giant core will merge. If their combined mass exceeds the [[Oppenheimer-Volkoff limit]] then the two will collapse into a [[black hole]], resulting in a supernova that disperses the outer layers of the star. Otherwise, the two will coalesce into a single neutron star. The surface of the neutron star is very hot, with temperatures exceeding 10<sup>9</sup> [[Kelvin|K]]: hotter than the cores of all but the most massive stars. This heat is dominated either by [[nuclear fusion]] in the accreting gas or by compression of the gas by the neutron star's gravity.<ref name=eich89>{{cite journal|last=Eich|first=Chris|coauthors=Zimmerman, Mark; Thorne, Kip; Żytkow, Anna|title=Giant and supergiant stars with degenerate neutron cores|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|year=1989|month=November|volume=346|issue=1|pages=277–283|doi=10.1086/168008|bibcode=1989ApJ...346..277E}}</ref><ref name=cannon92>{{cite journal|last=Cannon|first=Robert|coauthors=Eggleton, Peter; Żytkow, Anna; Podsialowsky, Philip|title=The structure and evolution of Thorne-Zytkow objects|journal=Astrophysical Journal|year=1992|month=February|volume=386|issue=1|pages=206–214|doi=10.1086/171006|bibcode=1992ApJ...386..206C}}</ref> Because of the high temperature, unusual nuclear processes may take place as the envelope of the red giant falls onto the neutron star's surface. [[Hydrogen]] may fuse to produce a different mixture of [[isotope]]s than it does in ordinary [[stellar nucleosynthesis]], and some astronomers have proposed that the [[Rp-process|rapid proton nucleosynthesis]] that occurs in supernovae also takes place inside Thorne–Żytkow objects.<ref name=cannon93>{{cite journal|last=Cannon|first=Robert|title=Massive Thorne–Żytkow Objects – Structure and Nucleosynthesis|journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society|year=1993|month=August|volume=263|issue=4|pages=817|url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1993MNRAS.263..817C|bibcode = 1993MNRAS.263..817C }}</ref> Observationally, a Thorne–Żytkow object may resemble a [[red supergiant]] or, if it is hot enough to blow off the hydrogen-rich surface layers, a nitrogen-rich [[Wolf–Rayet star]] (type WN8). ==See also== * [[Quasi-star]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Star}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Thorne-Zytkow object}} [[Category:Star types]] [[Category:Stellar evolution]] [[Category:Red giants]] [[Category:Neutron stars]]
